column1: Without this enzyme, bilirubin can build up in the body and lead to jaundice (yellow discoloration of skin and eyes) and damage to the brain, muscles, and nerves.
Parents who are carriers (with just one defective gene) have about half the enzyme activity of a normal adult, but do not have symptoms.
- Confusion and changes in thinking - Yellow skin (jaundice) and yellow in the whites of the eyes (icterus), which begin a few days after birth and get worse over time
Light treatment (phototherapy) is needed throughout a person's life.
In infants, this is done using bilirubin lights (bili or 'blue' lights).
A liver transplant can be done in some people with type 1 disease.
Calcium compounds are sometimes used to remove bilirubin in the gut.
